title: 107_hr2303
content: The "Ethanol and Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2001" is cited as the short title. It introduces a credit for property used in the retail sale or business use of E85 ethanol and neat biodiesel under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The E85 ethanol and biodiesel credit under section 38 allows a 50% credit on qualified fuel property placed in service, with a maximum limit of $50,000 per year. Qualified fuel property includes vehicle refueling and business use property, specifically for E85 ethanol and neat biodiesel. The term 'qualified business use property' refers to property used for depreciation, with the original use starting with the taxpayer, and used in the consumption of E85 ethanol or neat biodiesel in their trade or business. 'E85 ethanol' is defined as fuel with at least 85% ethanol, while 'neat biodiesel' is diesel fuel with at least 85% non-petroleum content. The section excludes property placed in service after December 31, 2007. Amendments include adding the E85 ethanol and biodiesel credit to the tax code. Unused credits from section 45G cannot be carried back before January 1, 2001. The table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the tax code is amended to include the E85 ethanol and biodiesel credit. Unused credits from section 45G cannot be carried back before January 1, 2001. The tax code is amended to include a credit for the retail sale of E85 ethanol and neat biodiesel as motor vehicle fuel. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001. The tax code amendment includes a credit for retail sales of E85 ethanol and neat biodiesel as motor vehicle fuel. The credit amount is based on the gasoline gallon equivalent sold by the taxpayer. The term 'gasoline gallon equivalent' refers to the amount of alternative fuel with a Btu content of 114,000. A 'qualified motor vehicle' meets emissions standards for the fuel it uses. 'Sold at retail' means the sale for non-resale purposes after production or importation. The section discusses the treatment of fuel used in qualified motor vehicles before retail sale, ensuring no double benefit for deductions or credits, and the termination of the section after December 31, 2007. The amendments to the tax code include adding a new retail sales credit for E85 ethanol and biodiesel, restricting the carryback of the credit before 2001, and updating the table of sections. The tax code is amended by adding a new retail sales credit for E85 ethanol and biodiesel, restricting the carryback of the credit before 2001, and updating the table of sections. Additionally, subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code is amended by adding new provisions. The tax code is amended to include a retail sales credit for E85 ethanol and biodiesel as motor vehicle fuel, effective for fuel sold at retail after December 31, 2001. Additionally, a small ethanol producer credit is introduced. The tax code is amended to allow cooperative organizations to allocate a portion of the small ethanol producer credit to their patrons based on quantity or other criteria. The tax code amendment allows cooperative organizations to allocate a portion of the small ethanol producer credit to patrons based on business done, with an irrevocable election made on a timely filed return for the taxable year. An election can also be made for prior taxable years before the enactment of this provision. The tax code allows cooperative organizations to allocate a portion of the small ethanol producer credit to patrons by filing an amended return within 3 years of the tax filing deadline. The credit apportioned to patrons is not included in the organization's taxable income but is included in each patron's taxable income. The tax code allows cooperative organizations to allocate patronage dividends to patrons, which are included in each patron's taxable income. Special rules apply if the credit amount is less than shown on the organization's return. The tax code allows cooperative organizations to allocate patronage dividends to patrons, with special rules for adjustments in tax imposed on the organization. The definition of a small ethanol producer for tax credits is amended to increase the threshold from 30,000,000 to 60,000,000 gallons. The tax code is amended to increase the threshold for small ethanol producer tax credits from 30,000,000 to 60,000,000 gallons. Special rules are introduced for the small ethanol producer credit, allowing it to be used against minimum tax. Special rules are introduced for the small ethanol producer credit, allowing it to be used against minimum tax. This section and section 39 shall be applied separately with respect to the credit, with certain limitations and reductions in place. The tax code is amended to increase the threshold for small ethanol producer tax credits from 30,000,000 to 60,000,000 gallons. Special rules are introduced for the small ethanol producer credit, allowing it to be used against minimum tax. Section 87 of the tax code is amended regarding income inclusion of alcohol fuel credit. Section 87 of the tax code is amended to include the alcohol fuel credit in gross income. The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. SEC. 5. Extends expensing of vehicle refueling property for E85 ethanol until December 31, 2007. SEC. 6. Repeals limitation on deposits into Highway Trust Fund for alcohol fuels, effective for taxes received after December 31, 2001.
